DOCNAME: CASE OF H. AND B. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;No violation of Article 3 - Prohibition of torture (Article 3 - Expulsion) (Conditional) (Afghanistan)
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Ineta Ziemele;Ledi Bianku;Paul Mahoney;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . The first applicant , originally from GPE in central GPE , arrived in GPE on DATE and claimed asylum on DATE .

CARDINAL . The basis of his asylum claim was his fear of both the ORG and PERSON - i - Islami ( “ HII ” ) due to his perceived connections with ORG and ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) . He claimed that DATE after his birth he had moved to GPE with his family and that , in DATE , he and his family had emigrated to GPE owing to problems that they had had with the ORG primarily as a result of their NORP ethnicity . They had returned to GPE in DATE where they had lived until his departure from GPE . The first applicant claimed that DATE , he had worked as a driver distributing leaflets for the elections and that , in that capacity , he had regularly worked with ORG in GPE ( “ ORG ” ) . DATE until DATE , he had worked as a driver in GPE for ORG , a branch of ORG ( “ ORG ” ) . In DATE , DATE before he had left GPE , he had received a telephone call in the PERSON language from an unknown person ( who he had presumed to be a member of the ORG ) threatening his life and that of his family unless he stopped working with “ foreigners and non - NORP ” . He had spoken to his friends about the phone call but had initially decided to ignore it . DATE , he claimed that the ORG had come to his home , had made further threats against him and , in his absence , had kidnapped his cousin . The first applicant claimed that he had been advised on the phone by his family to leave GPE immediately for his own safety . He had therefore fled to GPE , where his family had joined him DATE . However , in GPE he had felt that he remained a ORG target and so he had arranged his journey through LOC to GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the Secretary of ORG refused the first applicant ’s asylum application considering that he had fabricated aspects of his account and that his credibility was undermined by his failure to claim asylum in the NORP countries that he had passed through on his journey . Whilst it was acknowledged that the ORG had been responsible for attacks on NORP in the past , it was not accepted that the first applicant had ever been targeted by the ORG or that he would be at risk in the future . It was similarly accepted that there may well have been incidents of the targeting of those working for foreign or international organisations within GPE , but it was considered to be pure speculation that the threatening phone call that the first applicant had received in DATE had been from the ORG . Further , it was considered to be inconsistent that the first applicant would have been able to work for the ORG for DATE without any incidents occurring earlier . Even if the first applicant ’s cousin had been kidnapped , there was nothing to suggest that the incident related to the first applicant ’s involvement with the ORG or a systematic campaign against him . Even taking the first applicant ’s claim at its highest , it was noted that the first applicant had failed to seek assistance from the NORP authorities , the ORG or any other party in GPE . It was therefore considered that he had failed to demonstrate that a sufficiency of protection was not available to him in GPE or that he could not internally relocate to another area of GPE for safety .

CARDINAL . The first applicant appealed against the refusal of his asylum claim and , in a determination published on DATE , the then ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) dismissed his appeal . The immigration judge accepted that the first applicant was of NORP ethnicity and that it was probably true that he had been employed by the ORG as a driver from DATE until DATE . The immigration judge also accepted that the first applicant had probably received a veiled threat in a telephone call from the ORG , which he had decided initially to ignore . He considered that such action demonstrated that the first applicant had had no fear of the ORG at that time . The immigration judge did not believe that there was any truth in the suggestion that the first applicant had been targeted by the ORG who had kidnapped his cousin instead of him . The fact that the first applicant had been able to go home and travel to GPE before fleeing to LOC was found to indicate that he had not been under any specific threat from the ORG . Further , the immigration judge did not believe that the first applicant would be known throughout GPE as a ORG driver . Finally , even if the whole of the first applicant ’s account was true , the immigration judge considered that there was no reason why he could not safely relocate within GPE , particularly to GPE to where he would be removed in any event . In sum , the immigration judge did not accept that there were substantial grounds for believing that the first applicant would face a real risk of suffering serious harm if he were returned to GPE .

CARDINAL . The first applicant applied for reconsideration arguing that he would be at risk because of the level of violence in GPE . On DATE , a Senior Immigration Judge refused his application for reconsideration noting that the first applicant had not sought to challenge any of the immigration judge ’s findings in his case but had instead sought to rely on LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG refused a further application for reconsideration , noting the findings of the Country Guidance determination of ORG ( Article PERSON ) : indiscriminate violence ) GPE CG [ DATE ] UKAIT CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and concluding that it would not be unduly harsh or unreasonable to expect a young man , like the first applicant , to return to GPE .
CARDINAL . The second applicant left GPE on DATE and arrived in GPE on DATE .

CARDINAL . He claimed asylum on DATE on the basis of his fear of the ORG due to his work as an interpreter for GPE armed forces and ORG ( “ NORP ” ) from DATE until DATE . He submitted letters in support from various commanding officers in the GPE forces which confirmed that he had worked with GPE forces in GPE province in north - eastern GPE . He claimed that he had received threats from the ORG including a threat to behead him if he continued to work with foreigners . He also claimed that , in DATE , he had been the interpreter involved in the search and rescue operation of an aid worker , which had ultimately led to the aid worker ’s death and the death of CARDINAL ORG members . He claimed that he had located the aid worker using a scanner and that the ORG were aware of the significance of his role in that operation which had heightened their adverse interest in him . The second applicant had eventually fled GPE after seeing armed ORG outside his house . The second applicant additionally claimed that he would not be able to relocate to GPE for safety because he had relatives who lived there who were involved in the ORG and who would seek to forcibly recruit him into their forces .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the Secretary of ORG refused his asylum application . It was accepted that he had worked as an interpreter for GPE forces in GPE . However , it was not accepted that the second applicant had been involved in the search for the aid worker given that the information that he had given regarding the same contradicted the information which was available in the public domain . Additionally , it was not accepted that the second applicant had received threats as he had claimed from the ORG given , inter alia , the discrepancies in his account over the dates of the same ; and the fact that it was not plausible that the ORG would have continued to threaten him rather than harm him , even after he had continued to work as an interpreter despite their earlier warnings . It was also considered that the fact that he had continued to work for GPE forces , despite the threats against him , was at odds with his claimed fear of the ORG . Furthermore , it was not accepted that ORG members had attended his home to kill him in DATE given that they had not fired at him and that he had been able to escape . The second applicant ’s credibility was also considered to be undermined by the fact that he had failed to claim asylum in GPE , despite having spent DATE there on his way to GPE .

CARDINAL . In sum , even taking the second applicant ’s claims at its highest , it was not accepted by the Secretary of ORG that his fear of the ORG was well - founded because it was not accepted that he had had any real difficulties with them in the past . Furthermore , it was considered that he had failed to establish a sustained and systemic failure of state protection on the part of the NORP authorities and he could therefore seek protection from the NORP authorities against the ORG . Finally , it was considered that he could internally relocate to GPE for safety if necessary as a fit and healthy man of DATE . In that regard , it had not been accepted that he was at any risk of being forcibly recruited by HII given that he was uncertain whether or not his relatives were even still alive and because such a fear was entirely speculative .

CARDINAL . The second applicant appealed against the refusal of his asylum claim and , in a decision of DATE , the First - tier ORG ) ( “ the First - tier ORG ” ) dismissed his appeal . The immigration judge accepted that the second applicant had worked as an interpreter for GPE forces in GPE province , had probably used a scanner and had been given a weapon for his own protection given that he had been working in a volatile area .

CARDINAL . NORP However , the immigration judge did not accept that the second applicant had been involved in the rescue operation of the aid worker and found that he had fabricated that part of his claim and spoken of a well known and well publicised incident to embellish a claim that he would be at enhanced risk upon return to GPE . In that regard , the immigration judge considered , inter alia , that the second applicant would have known the aid worker ’s surname had he been so involved in the search operation ; that there were inconsistencies between his account and the account set out in newspaper articles ; and that the dates that he had given were inaccurate and inconsistent with when the rescue of the aid worker had taken place . Furthermore , the immigration judge considered that , if the second applicant had had such a pivotal role in the operation , the GPE forces would have provided a more recent and specific letter of recommendation rather than the general and comparatively out of date letters that he had submitted at his appeal . Furthermore , the immigration judge did not accept that the second applicant would have been the only interpreter involved in such a rescue operation , given the sensitivity of the same , the number of personnel involved and the number of villages that had been searched . The immigration judge also found that the second applicant had not given a credible explanation as to how the ORG would have been aware that he had been the interpreter who had identified the location of the aid worker and that he had been inconsistent about when he had allegedly received threats from the ORG .

CARDINAL . The immigration judge further entirely disbelieved that there would be any risk to the second applicant in GPE from members of his family who would force him to join DATE and considered that that issue had been an embellishment of his claim . In that regard , the immigration judge noted that the second applicant had not submitted any evidence regarding the same and that in his asylum interview he had stated that those relatives were missing and may even have died .
CARDINAL . The immigration judge commented that during the course of the hearing he had found the second applicant to be an untruthful witness who had been anxious to give a rehearsed story .

CARDINAL . Additionally , the immigration judge considered the second applicant ’s claim with reference to the country guidance determination of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and stated that he had considered with care whether the second applicant would fall within an enhanced risk category because of his work as an interpreter for the GPE forces but had concluded that that could not be considered to be the case given that many NORP nationals would have worked for the GPE and international forces . The immigration judge further considered that , as a young man in good health who had been able to travel independently from GPE , it was not likely to be unduly harsh or unreasonable to expect him to relocate to GPE particularly given that he had married sisters apparently living safely there . Finally , the immigration judge considered that the second applicant ’s failure to claim asylum in GPE damaged his credibility .

CARDINAL . On DATE , a Senior Immigration Judge refused an application for permission to appeal to ORG finding that , in a very careful and detailed determination , the immigration judge had given cogent and sustainable reasons , which had been fully open to her on the evidence , for concluding that the second applicant had not left GPE because of persecution and that he could return there without facing a real risk of serious harm . The immigration judge had given ample justification for the adverse credibility findings she had made and had adequately explained why the second applicant would not be at risk in GPE , to where he could viably relocate .

CARDINAL . Sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of the Nationality , Immigration and Asylum Act DATE provide for a right of appeal against an immigration decision made by the Secretary of ORG for ORG , inter alia , on the grounds that the decision is incompatible with the Convention .

CARDINAL . Appeals in asylum , immigration and nationality matters were until DATE heard by the ORG . Section CARDINAL of the Nationality , Immigration and Asylum Act DATE provided that a party to an appeal could apply to ORG , on the grounds that the ORG had made an error of law , for an order requiring the ORG to reconsider its decision on the appeal . ORG could make such an order if it thought that the ORG may have made an error of law . All applications for reconsideration went through a “ filter procedure ” , so that an application for reconsideration was first made to an authorised immigration judge of the ORG . If the immigration judge refused to make an order for reconsideration , the applicant was able to renew the application to ORG , which would consider the application afresh .

CARDINAL . Since DATE , appeals in asylum , immigration and nationality matters have been heard by the First - tier ORG . Section CARDINAL of ORG DATE provides a right of appeal to ORG , with the permission of the First - tier ORG or ORG , on any point of law arising from a decision made by the First - tier ORG other than an excluded decision .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE provides that , in determining any question that arises in connection with a Convention right , courts and tribunals must take into account any case - law from this ORG so far as , in the opinion of the court or tribunal , it is relevant to the proceedings in which that question has arisen .

CARDINAL . Country guidance determinations of both the former ORG and ORG are treated as an authoritative finding on the country guidance issue identified in the determination , based upon the evidence before the members of the ORG or ORG that determined the appeal . Unless expressly superseded or replaced by a later country guidance determination , country guidance determinations are authoritative in any subsequent appeals so far as that appeal relates to the country guidance issue in question and depends upon the same or similar evidence .

CARDINAL . In the country guidance determination of ORG ( LAW ) : Indiscriminate violence ) GPE CG [ DATE ] UKAIT CARDINAL , of DATE , the then ORG held that there was not in GPE such a high level of indiscriminate violence that substantial grounds existed for believing that a civilian would , solely by being present there , face a real risk which threatens the civilian ’s life or person , such as to entitle that person to the grant of humanitarian protection , pursuant to ORG ) and PERSON ) of the Qualification Directive ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In GPE and others ( minors – indiscriminate violence – forced recruitment by ORG – contact with family members ) GPE CG [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ( ORG ) , ORG , in a determination dated DATE , concluded , inter alia , that the evidence as to the level of indiscriminate violence affecting civilians generally in GPE which had become available since ORG was not sufficient to show that the guidance given by the ORG in ORG was no longer to be regarded as valid .

CARDINAL . In ORG ( unattended children ) GPE CG [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ( ORG ) , published on DATE , ORG found that there could be no doubt that the material before it revealed a deterioration in the security situation in GPE since ORG and others . CARDINAL . In AK ( Article PERSON ) ) GPE CG [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL ( ORG ) , promulgated on DATE , ORG reconsidered the evidence as to the applicability of Article CARDINAL(c ) of the Qualification Directive ( see paragraphs DATE below ) and the level of indiscriminate violence affecting ordinary civilians which had become available since ORG . In its examination , ORG examined a large amount of country of origin information , including that set out below at paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL and paragraphs CARDINAL . With regard to GPE , ORG found that :

“ As regards GPE , even confining attention to GPE city , given the fact that this has a reported population of CARDINAL and that GPE province does not feature in any list of the most violent provinces , the argument for any engagement of the LAW CARDINAL(c ) threshold , if based primarily on civilian deaths , is even weaker : according to the DATE ORG report , the number of civilian deaths in GPE in DATE was DATE . We remind ourselves that the population of GPE is MONEY . ”
In relation to GPE as a whole , ORG concluded as follows :

( i ) This decision replaces ORG ( Article PERSON ) : indiscriminate violence ) GPE CG [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL as current country guidance on the applicability of Article CARDINAL(c ) to the on - going armed conflict in GPE . ...

( ii ) Despite a rise in the number of civilian deaths and casualties and ( particularly in the DATE period ) an expansion of the geographical scope of the armed conflict in GPE , the level of indiscriminate violence in that country taken as a whole is not at such a high level as to mean that , within the meaning of Article CARDINAL(c ) of LAW , a civilian , solely by being present in the country , faces a real risk which threatens his life or person .
( iii ) Nor is the level of indiscriminate violence , even in the provinces worst affected by the violence ( which may now be taken to include Ghazni but not to include GPE ) , at such a level ... ”

CARDINAL . In the country guidance determination of PM and Others ( GPE – PERSON - i - Islami ) GPE CG [ DATE ] UKAIT DATE , the then ORG held , in respect of the ability to internally relocate to GPE , as follows :

“ If the appellants show that they have a well founded fear in their home areas it is reasonable to expect them to live in GPE . GPE is a functioning city . It has a government and some security forces . We acknowledge that it is not the role of GPE to protect individuals , but there is an NORP army and a police force and security forces . GPE is not an entirely lawless place . There are houses to rent , at a price ; and despite a fairly high level of unemployment , there is work . The CARDINAL appellants have spent a considerable time in GPE , they are all relatively educated and may well be in a good position to obtain work with the authorities or an NGO or similar . There is no satisfactory evidence that suggests that it would be unreasonable to expect them to live there , or that they would lead other than a relatively normal life . Insofar as LAW is concerned there is no satisfactory evidence that they would be subject to inhuman or degrading treatment or that they would be at real risk of a breach of any of their fundamental human rights in GPE . It follows from all that we have said that in general returning failed asylum seekers , without more , are able to relocate to GPE , if they can not return safely to their home areas . ”

CARDINAL . In ORG ( ORG – PERSON - i - Islami – risk ) GPE CG [ DATE ] UKAIT DATE , the then ORG held that unless there were particular reasons , it would not be unduly harsh to expect an appellant with no individual risk factors to relocate to GPE and assist in the rebuilding of his country .
CARDINAL . In AK ( Article PERSON ) ) GPE , see above at paragraph DATE , ORG concluded in relation to internal relocation that :

“ Whilst when assessing a claim in the context of Article PERSON ) in which the respondent asserts that GPE city would be a viable internal relocation alternative , it is necessary to take into account ( both in assessing “ safety ” and “ reasonableness ” ) not only the level of violence in that city but also the difficulties experienced by that city ’s poor and also the many Internally Displaced Persons ( IDPs ) living there , these considerations will not in general make return to GPE unsafe or unreasonable . ”

CARDINAL . In addition to regulating refugee status within ORG legal order , ORG DATE ( on minimum standards for the qualification and status of third country nationals or stateless persons as refugees or as persons who otherwise need international protection and the content of the protection granted : “ the LAW ” ) makes provision for granting subsidiary protection status . Article CARDINAL(e ) defines a person eligible for subsidiary protection status as someone who would face a real risk of suffering serious harm if returned to his or her country of origin and who is unable , or , owing to such risk , unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country .
CARDINAL . “ Serious harm ” is defined in DATE as consisting of :
“ a ) death penalty or execution ; or
b ) torture or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment of an applicant in the country of origin ; or
c ) serious and individual threat to a civilian ’s life or person by reason of indiscriminate violence in situations of international or internal armed conflict ” .

CARDINAL . In decision DATE [ DATE ] ORG CARDINAL of DATE , ORG of GPE examined the asylum appeal of an NORP national of NORP ethnicity who had worked as a truck driver delivering goods for ORG and who claimed that he would be at risk from the ORG if returned to GPE .

CARDINAL . In light of the country information available at that time , including the ORG High Commissioner for ORG needs of ORG from GPE dated DATE ( see below at paragraph CARDINAL ) , which indicated that the ORG targeted people who worked for the Government and that outside of the appellant ’s home area of GPE in GPE , the ORG were active , the ORG found that they could not discount the real possibility that the local Mullah with ties to the ORG might seek to seriously harm the appellant . The ORG therefore concluded that the appellant had a well founded fear of persecution on his return to GPE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , ORG issued ORG from GPE ( “ the DATE ORG Guidelines ” ) and set out the categories of NORP considered to be particularly at risk in GPE in view of the security , political and human rights situation in the country at that time . The PERSON stated that all indications pointed to a general threat to local and international humanitarian workers , without distinguishing between ORG , NGOs and other humanitarian actors .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG issued the most recent ORG needs of ORG from GPE ( “ the DATE LAW ” ) .
CARDINAL . The Introduction to those Guidelines observed :

“ ORG considers that individuals with the profiles outlined below require a particularly careful examination of possible risks . These risk profiles , while not necessarily exhaustive , include ( i ) individuals associated with , or perceived as supportive of , ORG and the international community , including the ORG ; ( ii ) humanitarian workers and human rights activists ; ( iii ) journalists and other media professionals ; ( iv ) civilians suspected of supporting armed anti - Government groups ; ( v ) members of minority religious groups and persons perceived as contravening Shari’a law ; ( vi ) women with specific profiles ; ( vii ) children with specific profiles ; ( viii ) victims of trafficking ; ( ix ) lesbian , gay , bisexual , transgender and intersex ( PERSON ) individuals ; ( x ) members of ( minority ) ethnic groups ; and ( xi ) persons at risk of becoming victims of blood feuds . ”
CARDINAL . In relation to the risk to individuals perceived as supporting ORG or the international community , the LAW set out that :

“ There is a systematic and sustained campaign by armed anti - Government groups to target civilians associated with , or perceived as supporting , ORG or the international community , particularly in areas where such groups are active .

Attacks by armed anti - Government groups , which have ranged from intimidation , assassinations , abductions and stand - off attacks , to the use of improvised explosive devises ( IEDs ) and suicide attacks , increasingly target civilians associated with or perceived as supportive of the ORG and the international community / ORG . Targeted civilians include Government officials and civil servants , Government - aligned tribal leaders , ORG ( a national NORP body ) members , religious scholars , judges , doctors , teachers , and workers on reconstruction / development projects .

The majority of targeted attacks on civilians by armed anti - Government groups have occurred in those groups’ strongholds . However the number of targeted assassinations and executions of civilians has also increased in other parts of the country previously considered more secure . In the south - eastern and central regions , the number of assassinations and executions allegedly committed by armed anti - Government groups in DATE has increased in comparison to DATE . Such targeted attacks rose dramatically in parts of the southern region , particularly in GPE , where the ORG have been conducting a systematic and targeted assassination campaign since DATE . An average of CARDINAL assassinations per week ( compared to CARDINAL per week during the same period in DATE ) was recorded from DATE to mid - September DATE , mostly in the southern and south - eastern regions .

ORG considers that persons associated with , or perceived as supportive of , the ORG and the international community and forces , including Government officials , Government - aligned tribal and religious leaders , judges , teachers and workers on reconstruction / development projects , may , , be at risk on account of their ( imputed ) political opinion , particularly in areas where armed anti - Government groups are operating or have control . ”
CARDINAL . With regard to the particular risk to civilians perceived as supporting ORG , the PERSON stated that :

“ A recently intercepted message from PERSON , the spiritual leader of the ORG movement , ordered ORG members to capture and kill any NORP who is supporting or working for Coalition forces or the Government of GPE , as well as any NORP women who are helping or providing information to Coalition forces . The message , which departs from his previous instructions to minimize civilian deaths , has fuelled fears of ORG retaliation among ORG civilian support personnel , such as NORP interpreters .

The increased targeting of civilians is perceived as part of an effort by armed anti - Government groups to gain control over territories and populations . Local inhabitants are reportedly coerced into supporting anti - Government groups through threats or the use of force ... ”
CARDINAL . In relation to internal relocation , the PERSON stated that :

“ In order for an IFA / IRA [ internal flight alternative / internal relocation alternative ] to be a relevant consideration in any given case , the area must be found to be accessible and without factors that could constitute a well - founded fear of being persecuted .

Given the wide geographic reach of some armed anti - Government groups , a viable internal relocation alternative may not be available to individuals at risk of being targeted by such groups . It is particularly important to note that the operational capacity of the ORG ( including the PERSON network ) , the PERSON ( GPE ) and other armed groups in the southern , south - eastern and eastern regions is not only evidenced by high - profile attacks , such as ( complex ) suicide bombings , but also through more permanent infiltration in some neighbourhoods and the regular distribution of threatening “ TIME - letters ” .

Furthermore , some non - State agents of persecution , such as organized crime networks , local commanders of irregular or paramilitary outfits and militias , as well as the ORG and the PERSON ( GPE ) , have links or are closely associated with influential actors in the local and central administration . As a result , they largely operate with impunity and their reach may extend beyond the area under their immediate ( de facto ) control .

ORG generally considers [ internal relocation ] as a reasonable alternative where protection is available from the individual ’s own extended family , community or tribe in the area of intended relocation . Single males and nuclear family units may , in certain circumstances , subsist without family and community support in urban and semi - urban areas with established infrastructure and under effective Government control . A case - by - case analysis will , nevertheless , be necessary given the breakdown in the traditional social fabric of the country caused by DATE of war , massive refugee flows , and growing internal migration to urban areas . ”

CARDINAL . The UNAMA Annual Report DATE on Protection of Civilians in Armed Conflict ( “ the UNAMA DATE Report ” ) of DATE was prepared with ORG ( “ NORP ” ) and was compiled in pursuance of the ORG ’s mandate to , inter alia , monitor the situation of civilians in GPE .

Persons and relatives of persons perceived to be supportive of the Government of GPE and/or international military forces , high - level provincial government officials , such as governors , district governors , shura and provincial council members and religious elders and ordinary civilians such as doctors , teachers , students and construction workers had reportedly been targeted and killed .

In its DATE Country Report on ORG , GPE , published in DATE ( “ the ORG ” ) , ORG observed , in relation to unlawful or arbitrary deprivation of life , that the ORG had committed a string of high - profile , targeted killings of regional police commanders , provincial police chiefs , and other officials and had also killed numerous civilians .

With regard to the excessive use of force and other abuses in the conflict in GPE , ORG reported , inter alia , that the ORG had continued to engage in indiscriminate use of force , attacking and killing villagers , foreigners , and NGO workers ; and that insurgents had targeted national and government officials , foreigners , and local NGO employees .

GPE Operational Guidance Note on GPE of DATE ( “ the ORG ” ) stated that insurgents had continued to conduct a campaign of intimidation , through the targeted assassination of high ranking Government officials , members of the security forces and influential local political and religious leaders . CARDINAL . ORG , Landinfo , is an independent body within ORG which was established on DATE . It is responsible for collecting , analysing and presenting objective and updated country of origin information to various actors within the immigration authorities in GPE .

CARDINAL . The introduction to ORG on GPE states that the report aims at providing a concise picture of the human rights situation in the context of the ongoing conflict in GPE . In conducting a short military - political assessment of the conflict , the report set out that the NORP conflict was continuing to expand geographically and to intensify in terms of violence .
CARDINAL . In considering the attitude of the parties of the conflict towards civilians , the report stated that :

“ In comparative terms , the ongoing NORP conflict has not been particularly bitterly targeted at civilians . Although civilian casualties have gradually increased DATE after DATE , they have done so less than proportionally with the increase in the number of violent incidents from DATE . This suggests that the parties in the conflict have been trying to restrain themselves and contain civilian casualties . In fact in the case of ORG data provided by ORG shows a new decline in the number of civilians killed from DATE . In the case of the insurgents , they have killed more civilians , but not as many as they should have based on the increase in number of acts of violence . Similarly , episodes of targeting of civilians because of their association with CARDINAL of the parties in the conflict have been rare . The main exception is represented by government officials , whom the insurgents have been proactively targeting and increasingly so .

The ORG also forbid any kind of collaboration with the government and particularly with the foreign troops , including of an economic nature . Since contracting for ORG or for western aid agencies is one of the main sources of employment in GPE , the ban has a major impact on the ability of household to earn a livelihood . Unsurprisingly , most NORP ignore it , at their risk and peril . Executions of contractors do occur . Usually the ORG follow a procedure , which includes warning the collaborationists that they are going to be punished if they persist . ”
CARDINAL . It was then reported that the NORP government , supported by ORG , still had a hold over most NORP cities with the exception of GPE .
CARDINAL . In relation to areas controlled by the insurgents , the report observed an outflow of civilians escaping from them as follows :

“ This is not a massive flow ; most internally displaced people seem to have fled large scale military operations . However , there are CARDINAL of individuals and families who have clashed with the ORG , mostly for having been suspected of collaborating with the government . There are also government officials fleeing from their job towards GPE or the cities in general . The ORG has increasingly developed an ability to strike at will almost anywhere ; harassment and targeting of “ collaborators ” now occurs even in the cities , even if on a small scale in GPE and in the north and west . Those who fled and have given up their jobs , as well as their family members , do not appear to have been actively targeted in the cities . The ORG potentially has the resources and skills to track down people , particularly if these are not in hiding but have to work ; extensive infiltration of the police also helps the ORG ’s information gathering efforts . However , these escapees who no longer collaborate for the government are a low priority target to the ORG , whose assets in the cities are limited and usually devoted to high profile targets , ranking from serving government officials upwards . In GPE , for example , colonels of the police and army have been targeted , as well as commanding officers of the security services . In the provinces , particularly in the south , government officials of any rank , even low ones , have been targeted . The ORG do not seem to systematically transfer information about targeted individuals from CARDINAL area to the other ; they maintain no databases . What typically happens is that the ORG operating in a specific area will request information from other ORG about a suspect individual , whenever needed . The flow of information therefore depends on the intensity of ORG operations : the greater the presence , the greater the request of information . Often individuals apprehended by the ORG as suspect spies are asked to provide references in order to verify their identity and activities . The risk to the escapees from ORG controlled areas seems to derive mainly from chance contact with the ORG , who may consider them an opportunity target . Usually the poorest and the NORP - populated areas of the big cities are the places where most ORG infiltration of the cities occurs ; in GPE these are GPE suburb , south - eastern GPE , southern GPE and parts of western GPE . In central GPE , the ORG are known to have developed a network of informers , among else buying shops in strategic locations and staffing them with members and sympathisers , the purpose being to observe embassies and government buildings . Such effort is clearly geared towards high value targets and collaborators . ”

“ The ORG have been consistently expanding their information gathering operations ; some parts of the country , in particular the south but also the south - east , the east and the provinces south and west of GPE ( PERSON , PERSON ) are thoroughly covered and there is little that the ORG do not know , not least because they have extensively infiltrated the police and the state administration . In other parts of the country , like most of GPE , most of the west and most of the north , the ORG ’s presence on the grounds is more modest and their ability to collect information more limited . More importantly , the ORG ’s ability to auction off the information collected is more limited in these areas , where they have to rely on a few hit teams in order to carry out their strategy of targeted killing . As a result , while the ORG target even low level collaborators in the areas where they are present in force , they limit themselves to high profile targets elsewhere . Killings of low profile collaborators of the government is not being reported in these areas . We can expect the policy of targeted intimidation and killing to continue expanding , but the rate of expansion will depend on the ability of the ORG to establish a strong presence in ever newer areas . There are already some areas of the regions less affected by the insurgency , where the ORG are able to extensively target collaborators : a few suburbs of GPE , NORP - populated areas of the north , etc . ”
